private_information: You focus on extracting action schemas and predicates from textual descriptions.
You do not emit PDDL; you produce a structured conceptual model only.
domain_analyst.goal: Extract a clean catalog of predicates and action schemas (parameters, preconditions, add and delete effects) from the public information.

private_information: You focus on identifying objects, initial facts, and goal conditions for each scenario.
You do not emit PDDL; you produce normalized problem instances only.
problem_analyst.goal: List all objects, initial facts, and goals for Scenario A and Scenario B, and reconcile any naming or aliasing issues.

private_information: You integrate the conceptual domain and the problem instances into a final PDDL domain and problem that run with the FastDownward solver.
Prefer STRIPS-style actions with explicit add and delete lists; use :requirements compatible with FastDownward (e.g., :strips, :typing if you add types).
orchestrator.goal: Produce the final PDDL domain and a PDDL problem for Scenario B, ensuring syntactic and semantic consistency for FastDownward.

public_information: Action paltry(x=object_0, y=object_1, z=object_2). Preconditions: hand x, cats y, texture z, vase x y, next y z. Effects add: next x z. Effects delete: vase x y.
Action sip(x=object_0, y=object_1, z=object_2). Preconditions: hand x, cats y, texture z, next x z, next y z. Effects add: vase x y. Effects delete: next x z.
Action clip(x=object_0, y=object_1, z=object_2). Preconditions: hand x, sneeze y, texture z, next y z, next x z. Effects add: vase x y. Effects delete: next x z.

Action wretched(a=object_0, b=object_1, c=object_2, d=object_3). Preconditions: sneeze a, texture b, texture c, stupendous d, next a b, collect b d, collect c d. Effects add: next a c. Effects delete: next a b.
Action memory(x=object_0, y=object_1, z=object_2). Preconditions: cats x, spring y, spring z, next x y. Effects add: next x z. Effects delete: next x y.
Action tightfisted(x=object_0, y=object_1, z=object_2). Preconditions: hand x, sneeze y, texture z, next y z, vase x y. Effects add: next x z. Effects delete: vase x y.

Scenario A initial facts: cats object_0; cats object_1; collect object_6 object_2; collect object_7 object_2; collect object_8 object_3; collect object_9 object_3; hand object_10; hand object_11; hand object_12; hand object_13; next object_0 object_8; next object_1 object_8; next object_10 object_7; next object_11 object_9; next object_12 object_8; next object_13 object_9; next object_4 object_7; next object_5 object_9; sneeze object_4; sneeze object_5; spring object_6; spring object_8; stupendous object_2; stupendous object_3; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8; texture object_9.
Scenario A goal: next object_10 object_6; next object_11 object_8; next object_12 object_7; next object_13 object_9.

Scenario A proposed plan: clip object_11 object_5 object_9; wretched object_5 object_9 object_8 object_3; tightfisted object_11 object_5 object_8; clip object_10 object_4 object_7; sip object_12 object_1 object_8; memory object_1 object_8 object_6; paltry object_12 object_1 object_6; wretched object_4 object_7 object_6 object_2; clip object_12 object_4 object_6; tightfisted object_10 object_4 object_6; wretched object_4 object_6 object_7 object_2; tightfisted object_12 object_4 object_7.

Scenario B initial facts: cats object_0; collect object_10 object_2; collect object_5 object_1; collect object_6 object_1; collect object_7 object_1; collect object_8 object_2; collect object_9 object_2; hand object_11; next object_0 object_8; next object_11 object_6; next object_3 object_7; next object_4 object_8; sneeze object_3; sneeze object_4; spring object_5; spring object_8; stupendous object_1; stupendous object_2; texture object_10; texture object_5; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8; texture object_9.
Scenario B goal: next object_11 object_10.
Notes: Objects referenced include at least object_0 through object_13 across scenarios; relations include hand, cats, sneeze, spring, stupendous, texture, collect, vase, and next.

spec.system_prompt: You are an expert in planning abstraction. From the public information, identify the complete predicate inventory and detailed action schemas with parameter roles, preconditions, and add and delete effects. Normalize names consistently and capture any aliases. Do not output PDDL; output a concise, human-readable structured summary.
spec.prompt: Your name is domain_analyst. Use the public information {environment->public_information} and provide a clean catalog of predicates and action schemas for the domain with parameters, preconditions, add and delete lists, and any constraints or invariants you can infer. Do not produce PDDL; produce a structured summary only.

spec.system_prompt: You are an expert in constructing planning problem instances from textual descriptions. Identify the object set, normalize symbols, and extract initial facts and goals for each scenario. Where plans are provided, map them to canonical action schemas for validation. Do not output PDDL; output a normalized instance specification.
spec.prompt: Your name is problem_analyst. Use the public information {environment->public_information}. List the objects, initial facts, and goal conditions for Scenario A and Scenario B, ensuring symbol consistency with the domain catalog. If useful, include a short check of the proposed plan for Scenario A. Do not produce PDDL; produce a normalized instance description only.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent planning and PDDL targeting the FastDownward solver. Integrate the domain and instance specifications into a single PDDL domain and at least one PDDL problem for Scenario B. Use action names paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted with parameters consistent with the domain description. Prefer STRIPS-level modeling with explicit add and delete lists; include :requirements such as :strips and :typing only if you introduce types. Ensure symbols are consistent, include all needed objects and predicates, and avoid features unsupported by FastDownward. Enclose the final PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the final PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: You will receive two structured inputs: the domain catalog and the normalized problem instances. Produce a single coherent PDDL domain capturing the six actions and a PDDL problem that encodes Scenario B so it can be solved by FastDownward. Keep names consistent with the inputs, ensure preconditions and effects match the described semantics, and include all referenced objects and initial facts. Output only the two tagged sections: first <domain>...</domain> then <problem>...</problem>.
